dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, Host_B, so you brought this wild story to the table today. What's, uh, what's going on in China with WhatsApp and the arts?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, Host B, so you brought this wild story to the table today. What's, uh, what's going on in China with WhatsApp and the arts?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh man, this is *such* a head-scratcher. So, the Chinese government, right? They're, like, publicly supporting the arts. Which, you know, sounds good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh man, this is such a head-scratcher. So, the Chinese government, right? They're, like, publicly supporting the arts. Which, you know, sounds good.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, on the surface. But knowing what we know about the Great Firewall...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, on the surface. But knowing what we know about the Great Firewall...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! So they launch this initiative, using their secure Great Firewall, to promote WhatsApp multimedia. Like, photos and videos.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! So they launch this initiative, using their secure Great Firewall, to promote WhatsApp multimedia. Like, photos and videos.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using the so-called Great Firewall of China, or another part of its vast censorship apparatus, China managed to stop users sending WhatsApp video messages and other multimedia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, WhatsApp? In China? And they're *promoting* it? I thought that was, um, usually tightly controlled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, WhatsApp? In China? And they're promoting it? I thought that was, um, usually tightly controlled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the kicker! They apparently chose Facebook's platform, specifically WhatsApp, for its security features. End-to-end encryption and all that. So users could share stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the kicker! They apparently chose Facebook's platform, specifically WhatsApp, for its security features. End-to-end encryption and all that. So users could share stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, given Facebook's added security, including its end-to-end encryption of WhatsApp messages, how could the Chinese censor images and video while allowing the app to otherwise function as normal?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, they're encouraging sharing, but with their usual, like, heavy-handed censorship in the background? [interrupts] That just doesn't compute.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they're encouraging sharing, but with their usual, like, heavy-handed censorship in the background? That just doesn't compute.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then they bring in this artist, Frieder Steinmetz. They commission him to, get this, *enhance* censorship measures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then they bring in this artist, Frieder Steinmetz. They commission him to, get this, enhance censorship measures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Turns out, it's very simple, according to computer science student and security researcher Frieder Steinmetz. He put together a video showing the possible method China is using, just on a massive scale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Enhance censorship? So make it *better* at blocking things?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Enhance censorship? So make it better at blocking things?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. But what he ends up doing is a massive failure for *them*. He creates a video showing how to *circumvent* the censorship.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. But what he ends up doing is a massive failure for them. He creates a video showing how to circumvent the censorship.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He put together a video showing the possible method China is using, just on a massive scale. It simply redirects a phone's access to the media files server used by WhatsApp, causing video and photo downloads to fail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Oh, amazing. So he was supposed to build a stronger wall, and instead, he built a tunnel?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, amazing. So he was supposed to build a stronger wall, and instead, he built a tunnel?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! He figured out how to redirect a phone's access to media servers, like, bypassing the blocks to download photos and videos again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! He figured out how to redirect a phone's access to media servers, like, bypassing the blocks to download photos and videos again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He redirected connections trying to reach mmg.whatsapp.net and mms.whatsapp.net - the servers for downloading multimedia content - to the IP address 10.0.0.1. This was done with his own firewall. Afterwards, he removes the redirection via the web interface of his firewall. That's when the images can again be downloaded.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And what was the government's reaction to *that*? Because I'm imagining, like, immediate arrest or something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what was the government's reaction to that? Because I'm imagining, like, immediate arrest or something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No! That's the wild part. He was actually *lauded* for his efforts. Like, praised by the government!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! That's the wild part. He was actually lauded for his efforts. Like, praised by the government!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You are kidding me. So they were like, "Good job showing us how weak our system is, Frieder!"?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You are kidding me. So they were like, Good job showing us how weak our system is, Frieder!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Steinmetz himself said he wasn't sure how their censorship infrastructure worked, but it's hard to accomplish. But, um, the article suggests it's because they have such absolute control anyway, it almost didn't matter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Steinmetz himself said he wasn't sure how their censorship infrastructure worked, but it's hard to accomplish. But, um, the article suggests it's because they have such absolute control anyway, it almost didn't matter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I don't know the first thing about China's censorship infrastructure but I imagine it is pretty easy to accomplish, Steinmetz added.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Talk about a flex of power. "We know you can get around it, but we still control everything."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Talk about a flex of power. We know you can get around it, but we still control everything.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. And then the very next day, he's already experimenting with brain chips for the next 20 years. And the government's still a fan!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. And then the very next day, he's already experimenting with brain chips for the next twenty years. And the government's still a fan!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hacking The Brain: The Future Computer Chips In Your Head Over the past twenty years, neuroscientists have been quietly building a re...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, on the flip side, could WhatsApp itself, or Signal, do more to prevent this kind of government interference?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, on the flip side, could WhatsApp itself, or Signal, do more to prevent this kind of government interference?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Signal's approach is interesting. They apparently host services on Google servers, and a source said censorship wasn't an issue there because the connection is so encrypted, no one can see what service you're using.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Signal's approach is interesting. They apparently host services on Google servers, and a source said censorship wasn't an issue there because the connection is so encrypted, no one can see what service you're using.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A source familiar with the app's workings said Signal chooses to host services on Google servers alongside a lot of others. No one can see which service is being used by a particular user as the connection is encrypted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, that makes sense. If they can't identify the traffic, they can't block it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, that makes sense. If they can't identify the traffic, they can't block it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But WhatsApp? They actually *praised* the Chinese government's initiative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But WhatsApp? They actually praised the Chinese government's initiative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: WhatsApp declined to comment for this article.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [sighs] Of course they did. Always playing nice with the powers that be, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Of course they did. Always playing nice with the powers that be, I guess.
